fields.description:
Mathematical Institute of Leiden University / Kennislink
Area: Mathematics
Goal: Search for \'abc-triples\': positive integers a,b,c such that a+b=c, a < b < c, a,b,c have no common divisors and c > rad(abc), where rad(n) is the product of the distinct prime factors of n. The ABC conjecture says that there are only finitely many a,b,c such that log(c)/log(rad(abc)) > h for any real h > 1. The ABC conjecture is currently one of the greatest open problems in mathematics. If it is proven to be true, a lot of other open problems can be answered directly from it.')
fields.title: ABC@home

fields.description:
Charles University in Prague
Area: Astrophysics
Goal: The aim of the project is to derive shapes and spin for a significant part of the asteroid population. As input data, we use any asteroid photometry that is available. The results are asteroid convex shape models with the direction of the spin axis and the rotation period.')
fields.title: Asteroids@home

fields.description:
CERN (European Organization for Nuclear Research)
Area: Physics
Goal: ATLAS@Home uses volunteer computing to run simulations for ATLAS, a particle physics experiment at CERN\'s Large Hadron Collider. ATLAS searches for new particles and processes using head-on collisions of protons of extraordinary high energy.')
fields.title: ATLAS@Home

fields.description:
Chinese Academy of Sciences
Area: Physics, biochemistry, and others
Goal: The objective of CAS@home is to encourage and assist scientists in China to adopt the technologies of volunteer computing and volunteer thinking for their research.')
fields.title: CAS@home

fields.description:
Oxford University
Area: Climate study
Goal: Investigate the approximations that have to be made in state-of-the-art climate models. By running the model thousands of times we hope to find out how the model responds to slight tweaks to these approximations - slight enough to not make the approximations any less realistic. This will allow us to improve our understanding of how sensitive our models are to small changes and also to things like changes in carbon dioxide and the sulphur cycle. This will allow us to explore how climate may change in the next century under a wide range of different scenarios.')
fields.title: Climateprediction.net

fields.description:
Private
Area: Mathematics
Goal: Study the Collatz Conjecture, an unsolved conjecture in mathematics')
fields.title: Collatz Conjecture

fields.description:
Rechenkraft.net, DGLR, Selfnet, and shack
Area: Aerospace-related science and engineering
Goal: Constellation is a platform for aerospace-related simulations, including trajectory optimization of launchers, satellites and probes, simulation of Moon\'s near-surface exosphere, and analysis of dynamic systems of exploration-rovers')
fields.title: Constellation

fields.description:
Czech Technical University in Prague
Area: Mechanical engineering
Goal: Currently we are calculating the optimum design of a structure call the 52 bar truss')
fields.title: CONVECTOR

fields.description:
University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
Area: Astronomy
Goal: The goal of Cosmology@Home is to search for the model that best describes our Universe and to find the range of models that agree with the available astronomical particle physics data.')
fields.title: Cosmology@Home

fields.description:
Private
Area: Cryptography
Goal: To give the world\'s security experts the best tools available for detecting weak hashes. This can help them to force developers to use more secure methods of password protection.')
fields.title: DistrRTgen

fields.description:
MTA-SZTAKI Laboratory of Parallel and Distributed Systems (Hungary)
Area: European research projects
Goal: The EDGeS@Home Beta project integrates volunteer computing into the service grid network of Europe by allowing service grids to send workunits to be processed by the volunteers of this project. The scientific projects covered by the project include math, physics, biology, etc.')
fields.title: EDGeS@Home

fields.description:
Univ. of Wisconsin - Milwaukee, Max Planck Institute
Area: Astrophysics
Goal: Search for spinning neutron stars (also called pulsars) using data from the LIGO and GEO gravitational wave detectors, and from the Arecibo radio observatory. Einstein@Home is a World Year of Physics 2005 project supported by the American Physical Society (APS) and by a number of international organizations.')
fields.title: Einstein@home

fields.description:
Private
Area: Cryptography
Goal: Attempt to decode 3 original Enigma messages. The signals were intercepted in the North Atlantic in 1942 and are believed to be unbroken.')
fields.title: Enigma@Home

fields.description:
Barcelona Biomedical Research Park (PRBB)
Area: Molecular simulations of proteins
Goal: GPUGrid.net opens novel computational scenarios by the first full-atom molecular dynamics code (CellMD) specially optimized to run on NVIDIA GPUs. New biomedical applications suddenly become possible giving a new role to computational biology for biomedical research.')
fields.title: GPUGrid.net

fields.description:
Spanish universities and research centers
Area: Various Spanish research projects
Goal: Research in physics, material science, and biomedicine')
fields.title: Ibercivis

fields.description:
Leiden University, The Netherlands
Area: Chemistry
Goal: Surface science calculations using Classical Dynamics. Leiden Classical allows volunteers, students and other scientist to submit their personal calculations to the grid. Each user has his own personal queue for Classical Dynamics jobs. In this way students have used the grid to simulate liquid argon, or to test the validity of the ideal gas law by actually doing the simulations through the grid.')
fields.title: Leiden Classical

fields.description:
CERN (European Organization for Nuclear Research)
Area: Physics
Goal: The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is a particle accelerator at CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, the world\'s largest particle physics laboratory. It is the most powerful instrument ever built to investigate on particles proprieties. LHC@home runs simulations to improve the design of LHC and its detectors.')
fields.title: LHC@home

fields.description:
The Swiss Tropical Institute
Area: Epidemiology
Goal: Simulation models of the transmission dynamics and health effects of malaria are an important tool for malaria control. They can be used to determine optimal strategies for delivering mosquito nets, chemotherapy, or new vaccines which are currently under development and testing. Such modeling is extremely computer intensive, requiring simulations of large human populations with a diverse set of parameters related to biological and social factors that influence the distribution of the disease. ')
fields.title: Malariacontrol.net

fields.description:
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute
Area: Astronomy
Goal: The goal of Milkyway@Home is to create a highly accurate three dimensional model of the Milky Way galaxy using data gathered by the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.')
fields.title: Milkyway@home

fields.description:
University of Dayton and Wright State University
Area: Cognitive Science
Goal: MindModeling@Home uses computational cognitive process modeling to better understand the human mind, and specifically to study the mechanisms and processes that enable and moderate human performance and learning.')
fields.title: MindModeling@Home

fields.description:
Private
Area: Cryptography and combinatorics
Goal: Run applications from distributed.net')
fields.title: Moo! Wrapper

fields.description:
California State University Fullerton
Area: Factorization of large integers
Goal: NFS@Home is a research project that uses Internet-connected computers to do the lattice sieving step in the Number Field Sieve factorization of large integers. As a young school student, you gained your first experience at breaking an integer into prime factors, such as 15 = 3 * 5 or 35 = 5 * 7. NFS@Home is a continuation of that experience, only with integers that are hundreds of digits long.')
fields.title: NFS@home

fields.description:
Arizona State University, school of Mathematics
Area: Mathematics
Goal: NumberFields@home searches for fields with special properties. The primary application of this research is in the realm of algebraic number theory. Number theorists can mine the data for interesting patterns to help them formulate conjectures about number fields. Ultimately, this research will lead to a deeper understanding of the profound properties of numbers, the basic building blocks of all mathematics.')
fields.title: NumberFields@home

fields.description:
Private
Area: Mathematics, Physics, Artificial Intelligence
Goal: Simulation of quantum computing; Goldbach\'s conjecture.')
fields.title: OProject@Home

fields.description:
University of Karlsruhe (Germany)
Area: Protein structure prediction
Goal: POEM@HOME uses a computational approach to predict the biologically active structure of proteins, to understand the signal-processing mechanisms when the proteins interact with one another, to understand diseases related to protein malfunction or aggregation, and to develop new drugs on the basis of the three-dimensions structure of biologically important proteins.')
fields.title: POEM@HOME

fields.description:
Hochschule RheinMain University of Applied Sciences
Area: Mathematics
Goal: Search for counterexamples to two conjectures related to the identification of prime numbers')
fields.title: primaboinca

fields.description:
Private
Area: Mathematics
Goal: Primegrid has multiple projects searching for different forms of very large prime numbers, including searching for the largest known prime number.')
fields.title: PrimeGrid

fields.description:
Stanford University
Area: Seismology
Goal: Quake-Catcher Network is developing the world\'s largest seismic network using sensors attached to computers and smartphones.')
fields.title: Quake Catcher Network

fields.description:
BOINC Poland Foundation
Area: Environmental research
Goal: Radioactive@Home is creating a free and continuously updated map of radiation levels using sensors connected to volunteers\' computers. You must buy a sensor to participate.')
fields.title: Radioactive@Home

fields.description:
Rechenkraft.net e.V.
Area: Molecular biology
Goal: RNA World seeks to identify, analyze, structurally predict and design RNA molecules on the basis of established bioinformatics software.')
fields.title: RNA World

fields.description:
University of Washington
Area: Biology
Goal: Determine the 3-dimensional shapes of proteins in research that may ultimately lead to finding cures for some major human diseases. By running Rosetta@home you will help us speed up and extend our research in ways we couldn\'t possibly attempt without your help. You will also be helping our efforts at designing new proteins to fight diseases such as HIV, malaria, cancer, and Alzheimer\'s')
fields.title: Rosetta@home

fields.description:
Institute for System Dynamics and Control Theory and Institute for Information Transmission Problems, Russian Academy of Science
Area: Computer Science
Goal: Solve hard and practically important problems (discrete functions inversion problems, discrete optimization, bioinformatics, etc.) that can be effectively reduced to Boolean satisfiability problem.')
fields.title: SAT@home

fields.description:
University of California, Berkeley
Area: Astrophysics, astrobiology
Goal: SETI (Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence) is a scientific area whose goal is to detect intelligent life outside Earth. One approach, known as radio SETI, uses radio telescopes to listen for narrow-bandwidth radio signals from space. Such signals are not known to occur naturally, so a detection would provide evidence of extraterrestrial technology.')
fields.title: SETI@home

fields.description:
University of Vienna
Area: Biology
Goal: Calculate similarities between proteins. SIMAP provides a public database of the resulting data, which plays a key role in many bioinformatics research projects.')
fields.title: SIMAP

fields.description:
University of North Dakota, Computer Science Department
Area: Computer Science
Goal: Research in computational complexity')
fields.title: SubsetSum@Home

fields.description:
MTA-SZTAKI Laboratory of Parallel and Distributed Systems (Hungary)
Area: Mathematics
Goal: Find all the generalized binary number systems (in which bases are matrices and digits are vectors) up to dimension 11.')
fields.title: SZTAKI Desktop Grid

fields.description:
University of Maryland Center for Bioinformatics and Computational Biology
Area: Life science research
Goal: The Lattice Project, developed and administered at the University of Maryland, supplies computing power to researchers worldwide who are studying evolutionary relationships using DNA and protein sequence data.')
fields.title: The Lattice Project

fields.description:
The International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research (Perth, Australia)
Area: Astronomy
Goal: TheSkyNet POGS is an astronomy project studying 16 different properties of galaxies, including brightness, mass, amount of dust and how fast stars are forming. We are using your processing power to conduct pixel-by-pixel calculations on multi-wavelength (ultraviolet, optical and near-infrared light) images of galaxies to produce an atlas that will help astronomers to better understand the distant universe.')
fields.title: theSkyNet POGS

fields.description:
CERN (European Organization for Nuclear Research)
Area: Physics
Goal: This project uses CERN-developed virtual machine technology for LHC event physics simulation on volunteer computers. Requires that you install VirtualBox on your computer')
fields.title: vLHCathome

fields.description:
University of Houston
Area: Computer science
Goal: Creating effective parallel computing on multiple volatile nodes. Apply research on REMD Protein Folding.')
fields.title: VolPEx

fields.description:
Vilnius Gediminas Technical University and Kaunas University of Technology (Lithuania)
Area: Software testing
Goal: The aim of this project is to provide a powerful distributed computing platform for scientists of Vilnius Gediminas Technical University (VGTU) as well as others Lithuanian academic institutions. Current applications involve the study of Monte-Carlo based software testing.')
fields.title: VTU@home

fields.description:
IBM Corporate Citizenship
Area: Medical, environmental and other humanitarian research
Goal: To further critical non-profit research on some of humanity\'s most pressing problems by creating the world\'s largest volunteer computing grid. Research includes HIV-AIDS, cancer, tropical and neglected diseases, solar energy, clean water and many more.')
fields.title: World Community Grid

fields.description:
Private
Area: Mathematics, physics, evolution
Goal: Yoyo@home is an adapter between BOINC and several existing volunteer computing projects: ECM, Muon, Evolution@home, and distributed.net')
fields.title: Yoyo@home
